G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000), exclusive of interest and costs, and therefore is within the original jurisdiction of the Massachusetts Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Berkshire County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Pittsfield, Berkshire County, Massachusetts, and the Property that is the subject of this action is located in Berkshire County.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, landowners owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors and persons foreseeably on or near their property, including those using adjacent public ways, with respect to conditions on the land that pose an unreasonable risk of harm.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: This excerpt is a concurring opinion criticizing the majority’s footnote suggesting that trespassers remain treated differently, and it does not itself clearly articulate or adopt a general rule that landowners owe reasonable care to all lawful visitors and foreseeable persons on or near the property, including users of adjacent public ways. The passage is focused on the conceptual problems of maintaining special treatment for trespassers, not on defining the scope of duty toward persons on adjacent public ways. Without the majority text, this quotation alone does not establish the broad duty described in the proposition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential. This tends to perpetuate, although on a smaller scale, the kind of tradition-bound and mistaken analysis that I had supposed the court was aiming to correct."

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, landowners owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors and persons foreseeably on or near their property, including those using adjacent public ways, with respect to conditions on the land that pose an unreasonable risk of harm.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that Massachusetts landowners owe a common-law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors, including a duty to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to avoid using their land in a way that injures travelers on adjacent public highways. Although the court ultimately finds no duty to alter the state highway itself, it affirms the underlying principle that landowners must exercise reasonable care as to conditions on their own land that create unreasonable risks to persons foreseeably using adjacent public ways. Thus the case supports the proposition as framed, limited to conditions on the land rather than requiring control of the public way.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware. … Although a landowner or possessor typically is not held to any duty with respect to public highways adjacent to or crossing his land, he must exercise reasonable care in the use of his land so as not to injure a traveler on the highway.”

Gertz v. E. S. Boulos Co., 451 Mass. 91,.raw_text: Gertz v. E. S. Boulos Co., 451 Mass. 91, 94 (2008)
Gertz v. E. S. Boulos Co., 451 Mass. 91,.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and/or person in control of the Property and the maple tree in front yard of the Property, owed a duty of reasonable care to Plaintiff, a foreseeable pedestrian using the adjacent public sidewalk, to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to prevent defective or dangerous conditions, including hazardous tree branches, from causing foreseeable injury.
Gertz v. E. S. Boulos Co., 451 Mass. 91,.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal procedure case about an investigatory stop, community caretaking, and the emergency exception under the Fourth Amendment and art. 14. It does not involve premises liability, landowner duties, trees, sidewalks, or any duty owed by a property owner to pedestrians. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for a landowner’s duty to maintain trees or premises in a reasonably safe condition for adjacent sidewalk users.
Gertz v. E. S. Boulos Co., 451 Mass. 91,.relevant_excerpt: There is no objective basis present here for believing that the defendant’s well-being or the safety of the public was in immediate jeopardy. Any objective view of the actions of the officer leads to the conclusion that he was in fact conducting a criminal investigation. After arriving at the scene, he quickly seized Knowles, made no inquiry about his well-being, and as soon as other officers arrived and took charge of Knowles, he proceeded to examine the contents of the open trunk for evidence of criminal activity.

Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341.raw_text: Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341 Mass. 640, 641–42 (1961)
Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and/or person in control of the Property and the maple tree in front yard of the Property, owed a duty of reasonable care to Plaintiff, a foreseeable pedestrian using the adjacent public sidewalk, to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to prevent defective or dangerous conditions, including hazardous tree branches, from causing foreseeable injury.
Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341.case_name: Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc.
Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341.support_reasoning: The case concerns a tavern keeper’s duty to protect patrons from assaults by other patrons and the applicable standard of care in that context. It does not involve landowner liability for conditions on real property, trees, sidewalks, or duties owed to pedestrians adjacent to the premises. While it discusses reasonable care and foreseeability generally, it does so solely in the context of barroom assaults, not hazardous tree branches or premises defects affecting sidewalk users, so it does not support the specific proposition about a property owner’s duty regarding a tree adjacent to a public sidewalk.
Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341.relevant_excerpt: “Now, as far as the tavern keeper is concerned, it’s the duty of the person in control of a tavern or bar to exercise reasonable or ordinary care for the safety of a business visitor and to protect him from assault by other patrons… The tavern keeper, however, is not an insurer of the safety of his patrons… The test is ‘foreseeable harm.’ And if the acts of an assailant could be foreseen, then the tavern keeper owed the guest or patron the duty to furnish him protection.”

Shiel v. Rowell, 480 Mass. 106, 110\u201.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that landowners may be liable for harm caused by trees or branches under their control when they know or have reason to know that the tree or branch is decayed, defective, or otherwise poses an unreasonable risk of falling.
Shiel v. Rowell, 480 Mass. 106, 110\u201.support_reasoning: The case reaffirms the so‑called Massachusetts rule that a landowner is not liable for damage caused by a neighbor’s healthy tree, and it explicitly confines its discussion to healthy trees. While the opinion notes that the traditional rule of nonliability is outdated as to unhealthy trees and cites Kurtigian for the proposition that the Massachusetts rule does not apply to unhealthy trees, Shiel itself does not articulate or apply a standard about landowner liability when they know or should know of decayed or defective trees. Thus it does not itself recognize the specific duty described in the proposition.
Shiel v. Rowell, 480 Mass. 106, 110\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The law in Massachusetts has long been that a landowner may not hold a neighbor liable for damage caused by that neighbor's healthy trees. See Ponte…; Michalson…. See also Kurtigian v. Worcester, 348 Mass. 284, 290, 203 N.E.2d 692 (1965) (rule does not apply to unhealthy trees). … The same rationale does not apply to the Massachusetts rule, which pertains only to healthy trees. See Kurtigian, 348 Mass. at 290, 203 N.E.2d 692.”

O\u2019Brien v. Christensen, 143 N.H. 37.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that landowners may be liable for harm caused by trees or branches under their control when they know or have reason to know that the tree or branch is decayed, defective, or otherwise poses an unreasonable risk of falling.
O\u2019Brien v. Christensen, 143 N.H. 37.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt is a New Hampshire criminal case about evidentiary rulings, closing argument, jury instructions, and public trial rights. It does not discuss premises liability, trees, branches, landowners’ duties, or Massachusetts tort law at all. Therefore it cannot support the proposition regarding Massachusetts landowner liability for dangerous trees or branches.
O\u2019Brien v. Christensen, 143 N.H. 37.relevant_excerpt: [No relevant excerpt is available because the opinion does not address landowner liability, trees, or Massachusetts tort law.]

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: A property owner’s duty of reasonable care includes an obligation to take appropriate measures when a defect is visible and long-standing and presents a foreseeable risk of harm to people using adjacent public ways.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that property owners owe lawful visitors a general duty of reasonable care as to all hazards, including snow and ice, and that this duty applies based on foreseeability, seriousness of harm, and burden of precautions. Although Papadopoulos focuses on conditions on the owner’s own property rather than defects on or affecting adjacent public ways, the reasoning is expressly premised on the broader Restatement § 343 duty to protect lawful visitors from dangerous conditions the owner knows or should know about. By abolishing narrow snow-and-ice exceptions and reaffirming the general duty, the opinion supports the proposition in substance, albeit not in the specific context of adjacent public ways.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’… If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.proposition: A property owner’s duty of reasonable care includes an obligation to take appropriate measures when a defect is visible and long-standing and presents a foreseeable risk of harm to people using adjacent public ways.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss a landowner’s duty to take measures regarding a visible, long‑standing defect posing a foreseeable risk to users of adjacent public ways. Instead, the case turns on lack of evidence of causation and, secondarily, lack of proof that the defendant knew or should have known of any hazardous condition. The brief reference to landowner knowledge (via Barry v. Beverly) is generic and does not establish the specific rule about visible, long‑standing defects and adjacent public ways stated in the proposition.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs also produced no evidence tending to show that the defendant knew or should have known of any hazardous condition on his building. See Barry v. Beverly Enter-Mass., Inc., 418 Mass. 590, 593 (1994) (landowner who has no actual or constructive knowledge of allegedly hazardous condition so that it cannot reasonably remove or warn plaintiff of the danger, cannot be found to have violated duty of care).”

Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.raw_text: Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mass. 37, 40–41 (2009)
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.proposition: Foreseeability of harm is a key factor in determining the scope of the duty of care in negligence cases.
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses foreseeability as part of the scope-of-liability (proximate cause) analysis in negligence. The court explains that liability exists only where the injury is within the scope of foreseeable risk created by the defendant’s negligent conduct and explicitly equates this with the common foreseeability test, making foreseeability of harm a key factor in defining the scope of the duty/breached obligation in negligence cases. Although framed under “scope of liability,” the reasoning directly ties negligence liability to foreseeable risks.
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The law does not impose liability for all harm factually caused by tortious conduct… Liability for conduct obtains only where the conduct is both a cause in fact of the injury and where the resulting injury is within the scope of the foreseeable risk arising from the negligent conduct. … Many jurisdictions employ a ‘foreseeability’ test for proximate cause, and in negligence actions such a rule is essentially consistent with the standard [of risk] set forth in this Section… Negligence limits the requirement of reasonable care to those risks that are foreseeable.”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.proposition: Foreseeability of harm is a key factor in determining the scope of the duty of care in negligence cases.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly links the existence and scope of a negligence duty to whether the harm was reasonably foreseeable. It states that a precondition to the duty of care is that the risk of harm be recognizable or foreseeable, and describes reasonable foreseeability of harm as the legal standard for determining tort duty, then applies that foreseeability analysis to define the defendant’s duty. This squarely supports the proposition that foreseeability of harm is a key factor in defining the scope of duty of care in negligence cases.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ … A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor. … Consequently, with some important exceptions, ‘a defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct, with respect to all risks which make the conduct unreasonably dangerous.’ … ‘To the extent that a legal standard does exist for determining the existence of a tort duty … it is a test of the “reasonable foreseeability” of the harm.’”}

Bencosme v. Kokoras, 400 Mass. 40, 42\u2.proposition: Defendant had actual and/or constructive notice of the hazardous condition based on: (a) the obvious, visible, cracked and drooping nature of the Defective Branch; (b) neighbors’ complaints and suggestions that Defendant have the tree checked by an arborist; and (c) Defendant’s own acknowledgment that he would “deal with it in the spring.”
Bencosme v. Kokoras, 400 Mass. 40, 42\u2.support_reasoning: The case concerns strict statutory liability of residential property owners for lead paint hazards under G.L. c. 111, §§ 197 and 199, and explicitly holds that liability does *not* require proof that the owner knew or should have known of the dangerous condition. It does not deal with common‑law premises liability, tree/branch hazards, or actual/constructive notice standards; instead it removes any notice or negligence requirement for compensatory damages. Citing this case to show that a defendant had actual or constructive notice of a hazardous tree branch is therefore inapt and misleading.
Bencosme v. Kokoras, 400 Mass. 40, 42\u2.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the trial judge’s determination that an owner of premises may be liable under § 199 without proof either that the owner knew there were materials containing dangerous levels of lead on the premises or that the owner was negligent in not removing the offending materials. Section 199…provides for strict liability, that is, liability without proof of fault beyond the owner’s noncompliance with statutory requirements… The language of § 199 virtually compels the conclusion that neither negligence nor knowledge of the risk is an element of liability….”

Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.raw_text: Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass. 560, 563 (1955)
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.proposition: Defendant had actual and/or constructive notice of the hazardous condition based on: (a) the obvious, visible, cracked and drooping nature of the Defective Branch; (b) neighbors’ complaints and suggestions that Defendant have the tree checked by an arborist; and (c) Defendant’s own acknowledgment that he would “deal with it in the spring.”
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.support_reasoning: The case concerns a slip-and-fall on melted ice cream in a supermarket and addresses when a storeowner has actual or constructive notice of a transient hazardous substance. It does not involve trees, branches, neighbor complaints, or an owner’s statements about dealing with a condition later, and thus does not support the specific proposition about notice based on a visibly defective branch, neighbor complaints, and the defendant’s acknowledgment. The opinion instead discusses constructive notice inferred from the condition and location of the spilled substance and the opportunity of employees to observe it.
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.relevant_excerpt: We said in White v. Mugar, 280 Mass. 73, at page 75, "The defendant owed to customers a duty to keep the premises reasonably safe for their use. He, however, is not an insurer of safety. Where, without action for which he is responsible, a dangerous condition arises, the law allows him reasonable opportunity to become informed of the danger and to take measures to remedy it. He is not liable, in such a case, unless he is negligent in failing to inform himself and to take appropriate action."

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 53 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s failure to take any action to remedy or warn of this known, dangerous condition constitutes a breach of his duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts negligence law.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The excerpt is a dissent focused almost entirely on proximate cause and the speculative nature of the causal link between the college’s alleged security deficiencies and the plaintiff’s rape. While the dissent briefly assumes for argument’s sake that there was negligence in maintaining an inadequate door-locking system, it does not discuss or establish the general principle that a defendant’s failure to act to remedy or warn of a known dangerous condition constitutes a breach of the duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts negligence law. The opinion therefore does not serve as authority for the cited duty/breach proposition.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "I agree that the jury could have found that the system for locking the room door was inadequate due to the defendants’ negligence, but I do not agree that the jury could have found that entry into the room was gained by disengaging a lock."

O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201,.proposition: Defendant’s failure to take any action to remedy or warn of this known, dangerous condition constitutes a breach of his duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts negligence law.
O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201,.support_reasoning: The case holds that, where a dangerous condition is open and obvious to a person of average intelligence, the landowner has no duty to warn or otherwise protect against it. Here, the SJC found the defendants owed no duty to warn or remedy the risk of diving into the shallow end because that danger was open and obvious, and therefore there was no breach. That directly contradicts the proposition that failure to remedy or warn of a known dangerous condition in these circumstances constitutes a breach of the duty of reasonable care.
O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201,.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the Legislature’s express abolition of ‘the defense of assumption of risk’ in G. L. c. 231, § 85, does not alter the plaintiff’s burden in a negligence action to prove that the defendant owed him a duty of care in the circumstances, and thus leaves intact the open and obvious danger rule, which operates to negate the existence of a duty of care… We conclude that, because the danger of diving into the shallow end of a swimming pool is open and obvious… the defendants had no duty to warn the plaintiff of this danger as a matter of law.”

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a direct and proximate cause of the incident on July 15, 2023, and of Plaintiff’s resulting injuries and damages.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that a defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of a later incident and resulting injuries. Kent v. Commonwealth holds the opposite in its context: it concludes, as a matter of law, that the alleged negligent parole decision was not the proximate cause of the officer’s shooting eight years later because intervening acts (INS custody and release) were a superseding cause. Thus the case is authority for lack of proximate cause in analogous circumstances, not for establishing proximate cause.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: “We also conclude that the Commonwealth’s motion to dismiss the plaintiffs’ negligence claims should have been granted because, as a matter of law, the decision of the Massachusetts parole board to release a violent prisoner to a deportation warrant of the Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS) was not the proximate cause of the plaintiffs’ injuries nor the original cause of the situation that led to their infliction eight years later.”

Doull v. Foster, 487 Mass. 1, 8\u20139 (.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a direct and proximate cause of the incident on July 15, 2023, and of Plaintiff’s resulting injuries and damages.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts comparative negligence law, G.L. c. 231, § 85, any alleged negligence on the part of Plaintiff (which is expressly denied) would not bar recovery unless greater than the negligence of Defendant, and Plaintiff’s damages would merely be diminished in proportion to any such negligence.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B, 6H.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for all injuries and losses proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, together with costs and interest as provided by law.
